title: Which party will win control of the Virginia Senate in the 2019 elections?
preds:
'Crowd' is very confident here of a Dem. Va. Senate take-over..
..Moving (even) closer to them at this late date. Can't find good-enough reasons not to.  https://wtop.com/local-politics-elections-news/2019/11/2019-virginia-election-guide-key-races/ http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2019/11/kentucky-mississippi-virginia-election-preview.html https://bluevirginia.us/2019/10/new-wason-center-poll-in-four-key-virginia-state-senate-districts-democrats-lead-republicans-by-14-points-on-the-generic-ballot-51-to-37 https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5446/Will-Democrats-win-a-majority-in-the-Virginia-Senate-in-2019

https://apnews.com/45a6cfc2e90d41c5a5155cbc3b4e1a02
@Censusguyz, this is what I'm on about, although the AP is (or needs to pretend to be) less sure of the outcome than I am (or pretend to be).

They are using the 2011 maps! Republican slanted.  The state Senate elections will be held using district boundaries enacted in April 2011. Those maps were approved at that time by the state Senate 32-5 and signed into law by then-Gov. Bob McDonnell (R). Republicans have a 21-19 majority in the state Senate. Ballotpedia has designated seven races as battleground elections. Of those, one is currently held by a Democrat and six by Republicans. Northam won 25 of the 40 senate districts during his 2017 gubernatorial election.

FWIW, some recently published polling data: https://bluevirginia.us/2019/10/new-wason-center-poll-in-four-key-virginia-state-senate-districts-democrats-lead-republicans-by-14-points-on-the-generic-ballot-51-to-37

Some current indicators seem to be pointing the Democrats' way, as also noted in @dbc1122 comments below. https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-democrats-in-fundraising-overdrive-ahead-of-crucial-elections-gop-up-slightly/2019/10/16/b2085768-f022-11e9-b648-76bcf86eb67e_story.html https://cnu.edu/wasoncenter/surveys/2019-10-07-va-leg-1/

With some hesitation, I'm upping my bet on a Democratic success in the VA Senate, largely for the reasons outlined in the Watson Center Report on their recent survey, as well as the original reasoning I cited in my first forecast on this question.  All indicators that I'm seeing point toward a challenge for the GOP to hold on to their two seat majority, particularly given that 6 out of 7 battleground states (apparently) are Republican held at the moment.  (I can't help noticing this is the opposite of the situation Democrats faced in the US Senate last year.)  The GOP do have a strong track record in Virginia for several decades--I'm weak on that knowledge, but that's my vague idea--but that seems to be turning the other way, with demographic changes.  Of course that's largely in Northern Virginia, and the vote in the rural Senate districts may still reflect that more traditional, White Southern demographic, giving them an edge in those seats.  But the swing districts are mostly in the more urbanized areas of greater Richmond, as well as Virginia Beach, and suburban DC.  There's time for Republican surge in popularity and energy--maybe partly as a backlash against the impeachment?  But we're getting close now too--November 5.  So yeah, I'm going to tweak a bit more in the Dems' favor.   https://cnu.edu/wasoncenter/surveys/2019-10-07-va-leg-1/ "This statewide survey finds Democrats carrying significant interest and enthusiasm advantages heading into the final stages of the campaign. Overall, 55% of voters interviewed report being “very enthusiastic” about voting in this election. Democrats have a 13-point advantage, with 62% “very enthusiastic,” compared with 49% of Republicans and 49% of Independents. We also find a 10-point advantage for Democrats among voters who report they will “definitely” vote. Overall, 78% of voters said they will definitely vote, with 84% of Democrats definitely voting compared to 74% of Republicans. "

Since the early 1900s, Virginia Senate had been Democrat-controlled. That changed after Clinton took office. It is possible that the news of possible Clinton culpability in the whitewater controversy, amongst other issues of that period, helped to sway Virginia voters. In the same light, the ongoing election interference controversy with the current administration may play a big role in tipping the scale back to the democrats

Another slight forecast adjustment for now (= increase to Dems), pending further developments + future polls: https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/a-majority-of-virginia-voters-want-democrats-to-control-legislature-cnu-poll-finds/2019/10/06/e954f862-e85b-11e9-85c0-85a098e47b37_story.html

Raising forecast slightly for now on a couple of (reported) general positives for Virginia Democrats....plus Trump essentially 'self-impeaching'. Ref.: https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/new-poll-finds-virginia-voters-focused-on-gun-policy-ahead-of-pivotal-election/2019/10/03/db034922-e472-11e9-a331-2df12d56a80b_story.html https://bluevirginia.us/2019/10/new-poll-democrats-lead-49-42-in-virginia-general-assembly-elections-59-say-theyre-certain-to-vote-northam-approval-at-47-29 https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/virginia/

I am making this forecast based off of current data that shows the partisan breakdown of the Virginia State Senate as of October 2019. As of Oct. 2nd, the Democrats have 19 members and the Republicans have 20. There is one vacancy as well.  https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_State_Senate_elections,_2019
We may have seen the last ever Republican control of Virginia as the world moves to the left.

Current make-up of Virginia's state Senate: GOP has single-seat majority, 20-19 (1 vacant seat) [1]. "In the state Senate, Democratic incumbents are defending just four seats against GOP opponents, compared with 15 Republican-held districts where Democrats are running. A departing Republican in Northern Virginia created the open Senate race in that district, which stretches from semirural farmland to dense suburbs west of Washington." [2] From PredictIt: 88% chance Democrats will win majority [3].  [1] https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_State_Senate
[2] https://www.wsj.com/articles/political-control-in-virginia-up-for-grabs-in-tight-election-11568971803
[3] https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5446/Will-Democrats-win-a-majority-in-the-Virginia-Senate-in-2019
Republicans are on the downswing after Trump, especially in urbanizing, educated states like Virginia.

Democrats have offered nothing but attacks on the President. It will have a major effect on everything. Democrats will cease to make any major gains over the next cycles up into the 2020 presidential election.

Recent N. Carolina congressional special election results might be slightly cautionary for Dems (in general). https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/republicans-won-both-elections-in-north-carolina-but-its-not-all-bad-news-for-democrats/
The state has been trending democratic and most (6 of 7) competitive seats are currently in republican hands. https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_State_Senate_elections,_2019

All but one of the 'battleground seats' are currently Red, and the Dems only need to flip two to take the majority: 
https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_State_Senate_elections,_2019#Background.  Most trends, including demographics, recent gubernatorial and presidential election results, and Trump approval ratings, also point Blue: https://bluevirginia.us/2019/07/virginias-state-legislative-elections-in-2007-vs-2019-whats-similar-whats-different-could-past-2007-be-prologue-2019.  On the other hand, lower off-year turnouts favor Republicans, as do sitting Governor Northam's modest approval ratings.

The Goode Olde Days are largely over for my Republican compatriots in Virginia--and even though statehouses don't matter much until redistricting, the Orange House's erasure of jobs from the military complex around Norfolk will not help them this year in the districts around there.  (I know--the Navy personnel who are posted there vote in their home states, which are not necessarily Virginia.  However, the civilian employees whose jobs have been erased for the wall project are Virginia voters and several have suggested to me that they and their erstwhile workmates may not be kindly disposed toward anyone who is a buddy of M. Petits-Doigts.)

Given that as recently as 2011 there has been no overall control in the senate, with 20 seats to each party I am surprised there is not an option for that.  Since 1991, the GOP has won the senate 3 times, the Dems 2 times, and twice there has been no overall control. (1995 + 2011). Of the 7 seats identified as possibilities to flip to the other side, 6 are GOP to Dem. I think that 3 or 4 of these (district 7, 10, 12 + 17) are likely to flip, which would give the Dems control of the Virginia state senate (https://www.virginiamercury.com/2019/09/04/cheat-sheet-the-house-and-senate-races-most-likely-to-decide-control-of-virginias-statehouse/ - https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_State_Senate_elections,_2019#Background). These seats have a combination of a small majorities and consistently voting for the Dems over the past few election cycles. There is also an early indication the Dems will be spending more money on this election than they previously have done.  Turnout in the 4 year election cycles for the senate and house has been lower than other years, probably due to the lack of congressional or gubernatorial elections (https://www.elections.virginia.gov/resultsreports/registration-statistics/registrationturnout-statistics/index.html). As a result of these factors, and that Trump has had a consistent negative approval rating over the past 2 years in the state (https://morningconsult.com/tracking-trump-2/) I am going to predict a Dem majority in this election. Open to revisions, new poll etc.

A total of 538 state legislative seats have regularly scheduled elections this year in Louisiana, Mississippi, Virginia, and New Jersey. Many of the races won’t be all that competitive. In fact, 158 Republicans will be running without a Democratic opponent, and 141 Democrats won’t face a Republican challenger. As a result, just 239 of this year’s races (44.4%) will feature a candidate from both major parties.(Rassmussen or Ballotpedia was source.)

Quick initial forecast: Recent history not much of a guide other than the Virginia Senate has been closely split (or tied) between R's and D's since 2007: https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_State_Senate_elections,_2019#2019_battleground_chamber Democrats nationwide (at least) are currently leading in a (nationwide) congressional "generic ballot": https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-generic-ballot-polls/
(A quick search did not find any overall or 'generic' polls re the Virginia state Senate election, though here is an early 'market' result (currently favoring VA Dems) from a separate prediction site: https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5446/Will-Democrats-win-a-majority-in-the-Virginia-Senate-in-2019 ) An excerpt from this 9/4/19 (Virginia news outlet) overview article: (https://www.virginiamercury.com/2019/09/04/cheat-sheet-the-house-and-senate-races-most-likely-to-decide-control-of-virginias-statehouse/)
"...Democrats feel like they have a solid chance at capturing the Senate. Meanwhile Republicans acknowledge they’ve got a fight on their hands, but say predictions of an imminent Democratic takeover are overblown." ...About 60-40 Dems, to start with, when also considering the (general + persisting) Trump un-popularity factor... (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/)
Demographic won't support republican leadership. There is hardly any chance of having a republican leader appear that will satisfy current needs in this deeply flawed 45 era.
